text: hi I'm Melissa Clark from the dining
section it's autumn so you're probably
eating a lot of squash right you're
roasting it you're throwing it into
soups and have you ever tried grating it
oh you have okay you don't need to watch
this video but if you haven't I'm going
to show you how
the only squash that I ever bother
grading is butternut squash that's
because you see this nice thick neck
here it's easy to peel and there's less
peel and more of the flesh because
butternut squash has such nice smooth
even skin it'll come right off with a
vegetable peeler
just try that with a kabocha now you
want to grab your squash very firmly
before you cut it accidents have been
known to happen and you're just cutting
it in pieces that are small enough to
fit in your food processor and then
obviously scoop out the seeds of course
you're gonna save them for roasting
right and then just grate it through you
could do it by hand with a box grater if
you don't have a food processor that
made fast work of it okay so we've got
grated squash looks like cheddar cheese
but it's not very versatile stuff you
can put this in risotto it will cook in
the same amount of time as the rice you
can add it to soups that don't need a
long time to cook you can add it to
muffin batter or a cake instead of
grated carrot or my favorite way just
saute it in brown butter with a little
bit of garlic and a little bit of sage
and fabulous Thanksgiving side dish
you
